title: Nearly 40 years on, why The Shining continues to haunt us
text:
When Stephen King wrote Doctor Sleep, his sequel to The Shining, he was strictly following the path of his own 1977 bestseller about writer’s block, cabin fever and madness in an out-of-season Colorado hotel. King has made no bones about his ambivalence towards Kubrick’s 1980 film, which takes his novel, dispenses with half the plot, and runs off with it in various other mortifying directions. To do himself justice he even wrote a more reverential adaptation for American television.

With respect to King, it’s no use: Kubrick’s film has too powerful, too eerie a grasp on the material to be anything other than definitive. For many of us, there is no Jack Torrance other than the one Jack Nicholson...
